content:
After a week of Parliamentary rebellions, Theresa May is set to beg the EU for more time. But what will she do with it?

 

THE SYMBOLISM was painful. Facing the reality of another lost vote in the Commons on March 12th, Theresa May lost her voice too. The prime minister croaked that, now MPs had decisively rejected her Brexit deal for a second time, by 149 votes, they faced “unenviable choices”. But the truth is that, along with her voice, she has lost control of the Brexit process.

That was brought home on the evening of March 13th when MPs voted once more against the alternative of leaving the European Union with no deal, on a motion proposed by a cross-party group of backbenchers not the government. This motion does not in itself eliminate the risk of a no-deal Brexit, since in both British and EU law it remains the default course in the absence of a withdrawal agreement. But it does mean that MPs have rejected not just Mrs May’s Brexit plan but also her old mantra that no deal is better than a bad deal.

Hostility to a no-deal Brexit is understandable. The government’s analysis shows it would inflict heavy economic damage, disrupting supply chains and causing chaos in ports, airports and on roads. Brexiteers claim this is misleading, as the EU would offer Britain a series of mini-deals. But the EU is clear that its contingency plans for a no-deal Brexit protect its 27 members, not Britain. To confirm this, Brussels this week expressed concerns about a British plan to cut most tariffs and impose no customs controls on the Irish border in the event of no deal. Such a smugglers’ charter would, the EU thinks, breach World Trade Organisation rules.

She fought the law and the law won

After her difficult week the prime minister might be forgiven for sympathising with Shakespeare’s character Dick, who declares that “the first thing we do, let’s kill all the lawyers.” For it was above all her own attorney-general, Geoffrey Cox, who scuppered the chances of winning recalcitrant MPs over to her deal, precipitating her Commons defeat.

It was not meant to be like this. Late on March 11th Mrs May had rushed to Strasbourg to meet the European Commission president, Jean-Claude Juncker and win last-minute concessions from the EU over the Irish “backstop”, an insurance policy to avoid a hard border in Ireland by keeping the entire United Kingdom in a customs union with the EU.The fear of Tory Brexiteers and of the Northern Irish Democratic Unionist Party (DUP) was of being stuck in the backstop with no escape. Mr Juncker duly agreed to a new legal text promising not only that the backstop would be temporary but also that the EU would do its utmost not to use it. Mrs May appended a unilateral declaration, which the EU agreed not to oppose, asserting Britain’s right to exit the backstop.

Her hope was that these new texts would allow Mr Cox to soften the warning that he gave about the backstop in November, when he concluded that there was no mechanism giving Britain a unilateral right of exit. Mr Cox duly advised that the new texts had indeed reduced the risk of being stuck in the backstop. But he went on explicitly to repeat his earlier conclusion that Britain would still have no lawful means of exiting the backstop save by agreement with the EU. This was enough for the DUP and most Tory hardliners to reiterate their opposition to the deal, despite Mrs May’s efforts.

What now? After passing their vote against a no-deal Brexit, MPs are expected to vote on March 14th to demand that the government go back to Brussels to ask for more time. Brexit day is March 29th, two years after Mrs May triggered Article 50 of the EU treaty. But there is provision for extending this deadline, subject to the unanimous approval of other EU governments. Mrs May is expected to take a request for such an extension to the EU summit that convenes in Brussels on March 21st.

Most observers believe the EU will agree. But its approval cannot be taken for granted. Other governments will want to debate over how long an extension to offer and to be told what it will be used for. The answer is simpler to the first question than to the second. Although there has been talk of a long extension of a year or two, to allow time for a complete rethink of Brexit, EU leaders are also anxious that Britain should not participate in the elections in late May that look likely to return many populists to the European Parliament. That means they will probably offer Mrs May no more than two or three extra months, which suits her as she has talked only of a short extension.

Her answer to the second question is fuzzier. She might use the extra months simply to keep trying to get her deal through Parliament. After all, she insists it is still the only one on the table. She may even take comfort from the fact that it was defeated by “only” 149 votes this week, down from a record-breaking 230 in January. Yet the EU has made clear that it will not reopen negotiations on any other aspect of the deal. Unless she can lure over more Brexiteers fearful of losing their goal altogether, or more Remainers worried by the continuing risk of no-deal, Mrs May’s deal seems doomed to keep failing.

That means searching for an alternative way forward. In the Commons this week the prime minister asked if MPs wanted to revoke the Article 50 letter, to hold a second referendum or to have an entirely different Brexit deal. Several Tories openly floated the idea of replacing her as prime minister, preferably with a more fervent believer in Brexit. And the opposition leader, Jeremy Corbyn, argued as ever that the solution was an election followed by a magical Labour Brexit that it would be easy and quick to negotiate.

There are three big problems with these ideas. The first is that, although MPs have made it obvious that they do not support Mrs May’s deal, there is not yet a clear majority for a different one. This might not change even if “indicative votes” on potential alternatives were held, as suggested this week by the Commons Brexit committee. Second, any other Brexit deal, such as a permanent customs union or the Norwegian option of joining the European Economic Area, would require not just the erasing of Britain’s red lines but also the passage of the withdrawal agreement, including the Irish backstop. And third, a short extension would not allow enough time for many of the possible alternatives, including holding another referendum.

It is tempting to blame the EU’s tough negotiating stance for the mess. Yet the bigger culprit was Mrs May’s incompatible goals. She wanted to leave the single market and customs union, to have no hard border in Ireland and to impose no new barriers between Northern Ireland and the British mainland. Any two of these were deliverable. But to get all three at once is impossible. The failure to accept or even to understand the trade-offs inherent in Brexit bedevils the whole process, no matter who is in charge of it.

这个抽屉动不动就卡住。
She got the key stuck in the lock.
她把钥匙卡在锁里了。
I can't get out─I'm stuck.
我出不去，我被卡住了。
We were stuck in traffic for over an hour.
我们堵车堵了一个多小时。
I hate being stuck at home all day.
我讨厌整天困在家里出不去。
I got stuck on the first question.
头一个问题我就答不上来。
I'll help you if you're stuck.
你要是难住了，我来帮你。
If you're stuck for something to do tonight, come out with us.
你要是正愁今晚没事做，就跟我们一块儿出去吧。
I've never known him to be stuck for words before.
我从不知道他也会有词穷句蹇的时候。
I was stuck with him for the whole journey.
一路上我一直没能摆脱他。

ex: n. 顶点；最高级会议；最高阶层

eg2: All their attempts at reaching the  failed.
他们攀登顶峰的一切尝试都失败了。
But are these the summit of our values, of our aspirations of society?
但这些是我们的价值观、我们对社会的抱负的顶点吗？
Should you reach the summit you would have only one desire, and that to descend and be with those who dwell in the deepest valley.
一旦你登上顶峰，你就只有一个愿望，那就是往下走入最深的峪谷里，和那里的人民一同生活。

他为穷人提供暂时的安身之处。
There were fewer temporary engineers to plug in in that city because of low pay.
由于报酬低，该城市雇用得到的临时工程师就更少了。

ex: n. 触发器；（枪的）扳机；（尤指引发不良反应或发展的）起因；引爆器

网络 板机；触发程序；启动
eg2: to pull/squeeze the trigger
扣扳机
He kept his finger on the trigger.
他的手指一直勾着扳机。
The trigger for the strike was the closure of yet another factory.
触发这次罢工的是又一家工厂被关闭了。
nuclear triggers
核引爆器
Nuts can trigger off a violent allergic reaction.
坚果可以引起严重的过敏反应。
to trigger an alarm
触发警报器

wp.unanimous resolution: 一致决定;一致通过的决议
wp.unanimous verdict: 全体一致的判决;一致裁决;一致裁定;一致裁断

ex: adj. 全体一致的；意见一致的；无异议的
eg2: So we have a  vote for that candidate regardless of how they finished in the Iowa caucuses.
因此不管这位侯选人在爱奥华州的表现如何，我们都会一致支持这位侯选人。
If jurors cannot reach a  verdict on their first vote, they must hear the views of the presiding judge, after which they may decide by simple majority.
如果陪审员们在第一次投票时无法达成全体一致，他们必须听取主任法官的意见，这之后他们可以通过简单多数作出决定。
One study has concluded that in almost half of non- cases, the justices’ votes do not accord with what one would predict based on their personal political views.
一项研究得出结论认为，在将近一半的非一致裁决中，大法官的投票与人们根据他们的个人政治观点所作的预期不符。

ex: adj. 可以理解的；可以了解的
eg2: Caution is , after the trauma of this year.
在今年的打击过后，谨慎是可以理解的。
It’s an  reaction but we need to balance it with prudence in dealing with the economy.
这虽然可以理解，但是我们需要在处理经济问题的时候谨慎权衡它的利弊。
The mother might have spoken with understandable pride of her child.
母亲谈到她的孩子时，也许有自豪感，这是可以理解的。

诉讼方或它的任何代表都不可以与陪审团有单方面的通信联系。

中国政府从来不把对外援助看作是单方面的恩赐， 而认为援助是相互的。

既然你已经着手这项工作了， 那就应该尽力完成它。

让那些只赢得女人首肯婚约但没有同时赢得她们内心最深处的激情的男人们发抖吧！

ex: n. 撤退，收回；提款；取消；退股
eg2: Atomicity requires that both  and deposit should happen in one go, or neither must occur.
原子性要求提款和存款必须同时发生，或者二者都不发生。
While China does not welcome the U.S. presence near its border, it wants stability on its western flank and believes an abrupt withdrawal of Washington's support for Pakistan could imperil that.
尽管中国不欢迎美国势力出现在其边境附近，但中国希望有个稳定的西部，并认为华府突然收回对巴基斯坦的支持可能危及其边境稳定。
Dreams about smoking were the result of tobacco , as 97% of subjects did not have them while smoking, and their occurrence was significantly related to the duration of abstinence.
与吸烟有关的梦是香烟被收回引起的，约97%的病例在吸烟时不会做那样的梦，这些梦的出现与禁烟的持续有极大关系。

Title: Parliament votes against a no-deal Brexit

paperStatistics.title: Parliament votes against a no-deal Brexit
paperStatistics.desc: After a week of Parliamentary rebellions, Theresa May is set to beg the EU for more time. But what will she do with it?
